title: Robert_F._Kennedy_Jr.
extract: Robert Francis Kennedy Jr., also known by his initials RFK Jr., is an American politician, environmental lawyer, author, anti-vaccine activist, and conspiracy theorist. He is the nominee for United States Secretary of Health and Human Services (HHS) in President Donald Trump's second cabinet.
trending_reason: The article on Robert F. Kennedy Jr. might be trending on Wikipedia due to his nomination for United States Secretary of Health and Human Services under President Donald Trump, which has generated significant public interest and controversy.

Kennedy Jr. is related to the trending article on the Laken Riley Act, as he recently selected Nicole Shanahan as his running mate in the 2024 presidential campaign, and the act was introduced following the murder of Laken Riley, which has intensified discussions on immigration and crime.

title: Murder_of_Laken_Riley
extract: On February 22, 2024, Laken Riley, a 22-year-old Augusta University nursing student, was murdered while she was jogging at the University of Georgia (UGA) in Athens, Georgia. Her body was found in Oconee Forest Park near Lake Herrick; her death was caused by blunt force trauma and asphyxiation.

title: Cheryl_Hines
extract: Cheryl Ruth Hines is an American actress. She is best known for playing Cheryl in HBO's Curb Your Enthusiasm (2000–2024), for which she received two Emmy Award nominations. She has also starred as Dallas Royce on the ABC sitcom Suburgatory (2011–2014), and made her directorial debut with the 2009 film Serious Moonlight. Hines is married to lawyer, and former 2024 United States presidential candidate and United States Secretary of Health and Human Services nominee, Robert F. Kennedy Jr.

title: 2024–25_UEFA_Champions_League
extract: The 2024–25 UEFA Champions League is the 70th season of Europe's premier club football tournament organised by UEFA, and the 33rd season since it was rebranded from the European Champion Clubs' Cup to the UEFA Champions League. This is the first season under a new format, with 36 participating teams that played eight games each against different opponents in a league phase, all the teams being ranked in a joint group. This will increase the total number of matches played in the competition from 125 to 189.

title: Guantanamo_Bay_detention_camp
extract: The Guantanamo Bay detention camp, also known as GTMO, GITMO, or simply Guantanamo Bay, is a United States military prison within Naval Station Guantanamo Bay (NSGB), on the coast of Guantánamo Bay, Cuba. It was established in January 2002 by U.S. president George W. Bush to hold terrorism suspects and "illegal enemy combatants" during the Global War on Terrorism following the attacks of September 11, 2001. As of January 2025, at least 780 people from 48 countries have been detained at the camp since its creation, of whom 756 had been released or transferred to other detention facilities, 9 died in custody, and 15 remain.
trending_reason: The Guantanamo Bay detention camp article might be trending on Wikipedia due to ongoing discussions regarding the future of the facility and its remaining detainees, as well as renewed scrutiny on its legal and human rights implications in light of recent political developments.

title: Mark_Milley
extract: Mark Alexander Milley is a retired United States Army general who served as the 20th chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff from October 1, 2019, to September 30, 2023. He had previously served as the 39th chief of staff of the Army from August 14, 2015, to August 9, 2019 and held multiple command and staff positions in eight divisions and special forces.
text:
{{short description|20th Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff and 39th Chief of Staff of the Army}} {{about|the general|the Irish athlete|Mark Miley}} {{protection padlock|small=yes}} {{Use dmy dates|date=December 2024}}{{Use American English|date=December 2024}} {{Infobox military person | image = GEN Mark A. Milley portrait (3x4 cropped).jpg | alt = | caption = Official portrait, 2023 | nickname = | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1958|6|20|df=y}} | birth_place = [[Winchester, Massachusetts]], U.S. | death_date = | death_place = | placeofburial = | allegiance = United States | branch = [[United States Army]] | serviceyears = 1980–2023 | rank = [[General (United States)|General]] | unit = | commands = {{plainlist| * [[Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff]] * [[Chief of Staff of the United States Army]] * [[United States Army Forces Command]] * [[III Corps (United States)|III Corps]] * [[International Security Assistance Force]] Joint Command * [[10th Mountain Division (United States)|10th Mountain Division]] * [[2nd Brigade Combat Team, 10th Mountain Division (United States)|2nd Brigade Combat Team, 10th Mountain Division (Light)]] }} | battles = {{Tree list}} * [[Operation Just Cause]] * [[Operation Uphold Democracy]] * [[Implementation Force|Operation Joint Endeavor]] * [[Iraq War]] * [[War in Afghanistan (2001–2021)|War in Afghanistan]] {{Tree list/end}} | awards = {{ubl|[[Defense Distinguished Service Medal]] (3)|[[Army Distinguished Service Medal]] (5)|[[Defense Superior Service Medal]] (3)|[[Legion of Merit]] (3)|[[Bronze Star Medal]] (4)}} | alma_mater = {{plainlist| * [[Princeton University]] ([[Bachelor of Arts|BA]]) * [[Columbia University]] ([[Master of Arts|MA]]) * [[Naval War College]] ([[Master of Arts|MA]]) }} | spouse = {{marriage|Hollyanne Haas|1985}} | children = 2 | relations = | laterwork = | module = {{Listen|pos=center|embed=yes|filename=GEN Mark A. Milley on Technological Changes to Warfare and its Role in the FY2021 Defense Budget.ogg|title=Mark Milley's voice|type=speech|description=Mark Milley on how technology changes warfare and its role in the FY2021 defense budget
Recorded 26 February 2020}} }} '''Mark Alexander Milley''' (born 20 June 1958) is a retired [[United States Army]] [[General (United States)|general]] who served as the 20th [[chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff]] from October 1, 2019, to September 30, 2023. He had previously served as the 39th [[Chief of Staff of the United States Army|chief of staff of the Army]] from August 14, 2015, to August 9, 2019{{cite web |url=https://www.army.mil/leaders/csa/?from=wiki |title=Chief of Staff of the Army | General Mark A. Milley |publisher=United States Army |access-date=December 11, 2018 |archive-date=June 24, 2018 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180624035954/https://www.army.mil/leaders/csa/?from=wiki |url-status=live }} and held multiple command and staff positions in eight divisions and special forces. A [[Reserve Officers' Training Corps]] graduate from [[Princeton University]], Milley earned his commission as an [[Armor Branch|armor]] officer in 1980. He later received a master's degree from [[Columbia University]]. He was appointed chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff by U.S. president [[Donald Trump]], making Milley the tenth U.S. Army officer to be chairman. As chairman, Milley was the highest-ranking officer in the [[United States Armed Forces]] and the principal military advisor to the [[president of the United States]], the [[United States Secretary of Defense|secretary of defense]], the [[United States National Security Council|National Security Council]] and the [[Homeland Security Council]].{{USC|10|151}} - Joint Chiefs of Staff: composition; functions His official portrait was unveiled at [[the Pentagon]] on January 10, 2025, but was removed within hours of Donald Trump's inauguration, an unprecedented step. ==Early life and education== Milley was born on 20 June 1958, in [[Winchester, Massachusetts]].{{cite web |url=https://www.congress.gov/114/chrg/shrg24274/CHRG-114shrg24274.pdf |title=Nominations Before the Senate Armed Services Committee, First Session, 114th Congress |access-date=October 30, 2021 |archive-date=October 15, 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20211015150510/https://www.congress.gov/114/chrg/shrg24274/CHRG-114shrg24274.pdf |url-status=live }} ''Page 581'' He is of Irish descent, and was raised [[Roman Catholicism|Roman Catholic]].{{cite news |last=Ryan |first=Missy |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/national-security/trump-biden-milley-transition-military/2021/06/22/44df70ea-c9f1-11eb-93fa-9053a95eb9f2_story.html |title=For military's top man, navigating the Trump-Bid
trending_reason: The Mark Milley article might be trending on Wikipedia due to the recent unveiling of his official portrait at the Pentagon, followed by its removal shortly after Donald Trump's inauguration, which marks a significant and unprecedented event in military history.

title: Bob_Menendez
extract: Robert Menendez is an American lawyer and former politician who served as a United States senator from New Jersey from 2006 until his resignation in 2024 following his conviction on 16 counts in a political corruption case. He was sentenced to 11 years in prison in January 2025. A member of the Democratic Party and the Cuban–American lobby, he was first appointed to the Senate by Governor Jon Corzine, and chaired the United States Senate Committee on Foreign Relations from 2013 to 2015 and from 2021 to 2023.

title: Trump_Shuttle
extract: Trump Shuttle, Inc. was an airline owned by Donald Trump from 1989 to 1992. The landing rights and some of the physical assets necessary to operate the shuttle flights were originally part of Eastern Air Lines and known as the Eastern Air Lines Shuttle. It operated hourly flights on Boeing 727 aircraft from LaGuardia Airport in New York City to Boston Logan International Airport in Boston, Massachusetts and Ronald Reagan Washington National Airport in Washington, D.C., as well as charter service to other destinations. Its IATA designator code was TB.
text:
{{Short description|Former air shuttle service of the United States (1989–1992)}} {{for|Donald Trump's private jet|Trump Force One}} {{Infobox airline | airline = Trump Shuttle | logo = Trump Shuttle logo, August 1989.svg | logo_size = 250 | caption = | IATA = TB | ICAO = TPS | callsign = TRUMP | aoc = | hubs = | focus_cities = | frequent_flyer = | fleet_size = | destinations = {{ubl|class=nowrap | [[Boston Logan International Airport|Boston]] | [[LaGuardia Airport|New York–LaGuardia]] | [[Ronald Reagan Washington National Airport|Washington–National]]}} | parent = {{nowrap|[[The Trump Organization]] {{small|(1989–1992)}}}} | key_people = {{bulleted list| | [[Donald Trump]] (owner) | [[Bette Nash]] ([[flight attendant]])}} | num_employees = | founded = {{start date and age|1989|06|07|mf=y}} | ceased = {{end date and age|1992|04|07|mf=y}}
{{small|(rebranded as [[US Airways Shuttle|USAir Shuttle]])}} }} [[File:Boeing 727-25, Trump Shuttle AN1132781.jpg|thumb|240px|A Trump Shuttle [[Boeing 727-100]] in 1989]] '''Trump Shuttle, Inc.''' was an airline owned by [[Donald Trump]] from 1989 to 1992. The landing rights and some of the physical assets necessary to operate the [[air shuttle|shuttle flights]] were originally part of [[Eastern Air Lines]] and known as the [[Eastern Air Lines Shuttle]]. It operated hourly flights on [[Boeing 727]] aircraft from [[LaGuardia Airport]] in [[New York City]] to [[Boston Logan International Airport]] in [[Boston, Massachusetts]] and [[Ronald Reagan Washington National Airport]] in [[Washington, D.C.]], as well as charter service to other destinations. Its [[IATA]] designator code was TB (later reassigned to Jetairfly, which became [[TUI fly Belgium]]).{{Cite web|url=http://www.al-airliners.be/codes/codes-alpha-19.htm|title=Codes IATA/OACI by airline|publisher=www.al-airliners.be|access-date=2017-08-21}} Trump's formal launch in the air business occurred in March 1988 when he acquired three [[Sikorsky S-61]] helicopters that belonged to Resorts International Airlines (RIA) used to shuttle high rollers to the [[Resorts Casino Hotel]] in [[Atlantic City, New Jersey]].{{cite news |url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/31464398/daily-record-morristown-nj-1998-03-24/ |title=Helicopter Service Shuttles Gamblers to Casinos |work=[[Daily Record (Morristown)|Daily Record]] |location=[[Morristown, New Jersey]] |page=26 (B10) |agency=[[Associated Press]] |date=March 24, 1988 |access-date=November 14, 2020 |archive-date=November 15, 2020 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201115022325/https://www.newspapers.com/clip/31464398/daily-record-morristown-nj-1998-03-24/ |url-status=bot: unknown }} The three green and orange helicopters were repainted black and red and emblazoned with the Trump Air logo.{{cite news |last=Chadwick |first=Bruce |url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/31464697/new_york_daily_news_19880327/ |title=Atlantic City Confidential |work=[[New York Daily News|Daily News]] |location=[[New York City]] |page=313 (24) |date=March 27, 1988 |access-date=November 14, 2020 |archive-date=June 7, 2019 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190607023252/https://www.newspapers.com/clip/31464697/new_york_daily_news_19880327/ |url-status=bot: unknown }} == History == === Formation === In the late 1980s, both [[Eastern Air Lines]] and [[Pan American World Airways]] operated [[air shuttle]] services in the [[Northeastern United States]], which were highly profitable even though the two airlines, as a whole, were not.{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1989/06/25/business/selling-the-trump-shuttle.html|title=Selling the Trump Shuttle|last=Landler|first=Mark|date=1989-06-25|work=[[The New York Times]]|access-date=2017-08-21|language=en-US|issn=0362-4331}} As the financial outlook for Eastern became more pessimistic in the late 1980s, the carrier began to sell its routes and aircraft. It organized its profitable shuttle operation into a separate company, headed by Bruce Nobles, with the intent of selling it to raise cash. Eastern chairman [[Frank Lorenzo]] met [[Donald Trump]] at a party, and subsequently negotiated the sale of the shuttle to Trump for $365 million, more than the projected cost to start up a similar airline, but justifiable if the airline achieved a high market share.{{Cite news|url=https://www.bostonglobe.com/news/politics/2016/05/27/donald-trump-airline-went-from-opulence-air-crash-landing/zEf1Er2Hok2dPTVVmZT6NP/story.html|title=Donald Trump's airline went from opulence in the air to crash landing|last=Viser|first=Matt|date=2016-05-27|work=[[The Boston Globe]] |access-date=2017-08-21}} For that price, Trump got a fleet of 17 [[Boeing 727]]s, landing facilities in each of the three cities that the shuttle flew to, and the right to p

title: Laken_Riley_Act
extract: The Laken Riley Act is a United States law that requires the U.S. Department of Homeland Security to detain illegal immigrants admitting to, charged with, or convicted of theft-related crimes, assaulting a police officer, or a crime that results in death or serious bodily injury like drunk driving. The Act also allows states to sue the Department of Homeland Security for alleged failures in immigration enforcement.
text:
{{Short description|2025 U.S. immigration law}} {{pp|small=yes}} {{Use mdy dates|date=January 2025}} {{Infobox United States federal proposed legislation | name = Laken Riley Act | fullname = To require the [[United States Department of Homeland Security|Secretary of Homeland Security]] to take into custody aliens who have been charged in the United States with theft, and for other purposes. | introduced in the = 119th | number of co-sponsors = 53 | acts amended = [[Immigration and Nationality Act of 1952]] | title amended = [[Title 8 of the United States Code|8 U.S.C.: Aliens and Nationality]] | sections amended = {{Usc-title-chap|8|12|II}} § 1182(d)(f)
{{Usc-title-chap|8|12|II}} § 1225(b)
{{Usc-title-chap|8|12|II}} § 1226
{{Usc-title-chap|8|12|II}} § 1226(c)
{{Usc-title-chap|8|12|II}} § 1231(a)(2)
{{Usc-title-chap|8|12|II}} § 1252(f)
{{Usc-title-chap|8|12|II}} § 1253 | public law url = | introducedin = Senate | leghisturl = https://www.congress.gov/bill/119th-congress/senate-bill/5/all-actions | introducedbill = [https://www.congress.gov/bill/119th-congress/senate-bill/5/text/ih S. 5] | introduceddate = January 6, 2025 | introducedby = [[Katie Britt]] ([[Republican Party (United States)|R]]–[[Alabama|AL]]) | enacted by = | passedbody1 = U.S. Senate with amendments | passeddate1 = January 20, 2025 | passedvote1 = [https://www.senate.gov/legislative/LIS/roll_call_votes/vote1191/vote_119_1_00007.htm 64—35] | passedbody2 = U.S. House of Representatives | passeddate2 = January 22, 2025 | passedvote2 = [https://clerk.house.gov/Votes/202523 263–156] | signedpresident = [[Donald Trump]] | signeddate = January 29, 2025 }} The '''Laken Riley Act''' is a [[United States]] law that requires the [[United States Department of Homeland Security|U.S. Department of Homeland Security]] to detain [[illegal immigrants]]https://www.congress.gov/bill/119th-congress/senate-bill/5 . Retrieved 29 January 2025. admitting to,{{Cite news |last=Demirjian |first=Karoun |date=2025-01-30 |title=Laken Riley Act Is an Effort to Target Migrants Accused of Crimes |url=https://www.nytimes.com/article/laken-riley-act-explained.html |access-date=2025-01-30 |work=The New York Times |language=en-US |issn=0362-4331}} charged with, or convicted of theft-related crimes,{{Cite web |last=Collins |first=Mike |authorlink=Mike Collins (politician) |date=January 8, 2025 |title=Text - H.R.29 - 119th Congress (2025-2026): Laken Riley Act |url=https://www.congress.gov/bill/119th-congress/house-bill/29/text |access-date=January 10, 2025 |website=www.congress.gov}} assaulting a police officer, or a crime that results in death or serious bodily injury like [[drunk driving]].{{Cite web |last=Cornyn |first=John |authorlink=John Cornyn |date=2025-01-15 |title=S.Amdt.14 to S.Amdt.8 to S.5 - 119th Congress (2025-2026) |url=https://www.congress.gov/amendment/119th-congress/senate-amendment/14 |access-date=2025-01-21 |website=www.congress.gov}}{{Cite web |last=Ernst |first=Joni |authorlink=Joni Ernst |date=2025-01-20 |title=S.Amdt.8 to S.5 - 119th Congress (2025-2026) |url=https://www.congress.gov/amendment/119th-congress/senate-amendment/8/ |access-date=2025-01-21 |website=www.congress.gov}} The Act also allows states to sue the Department of Homeland Security for alleged failures in immigration enforcement. The bill was introduced following the [[murder of Laken Riley]] by an illegal immigrant who had previously been cited for [[shoplifting]], on the campus of the [[University of Georgia]] in [[Athens, Georgia]]. On January 22, 2025, the House agreed to the Senate's version of the bill with a 263–156 vote.{{Cite web|url=https://www.nbcnews.com/politics/congress/house-passes-laken-riley-act-sending-first-bill-trump-sign-law-rcna188724|title=House passes Laken Riley Act, sending the first bill to Trump to sign into law|website=[[NBC News]] }} President [[Donald Trump]] signed the bill into law on January 29, 2025.{{Cite web |date=2025-01-24 |title=What is the Laken Riley Act? A look at the first bill Trump will sign |url=https://apnews.com/article/what-is-laken-riley-act-trump-immigration-2667d626139ddf5a16d1533516eab18f |access-date=2025-01-27 |website=AP News |language=en}} == Background == {{See also|Murder of Laken Riley}} On February 22, 2024, Georgia resident Laken Riley was murdered by José Antonio Ibarra, a Venezuelan man who had entered the United States illegally in September 2022, crossing the United States' southern border with Mexico near [[El Paso, Texas]].{{Cite web |date=March 7, 2024 |title=House Republicans push bill to detain migrants accused of theft after Georgia student killed |url=https://apnews.com/article/congress-laken-riley-immigration-ibarra-georgia-34b06b0829772900eb55c123fe151845 |access-date=January 10, 2025 |website=AP News |lang

title: Damir_Dokić
extract: Damir Dokić was a Serbian tennis coach. He is the father and ex-coach of former professional tennis player Jelena Dokic. He gained notoriety for being involved in various violent incidents in which he was verbally and physically abusive.
text:
{{Short description|Serbian tennis coach}}
'''Damir Dokić''' ({{langx|sr|Дамир Докић}}, born 1950s) was a Serbian tennis coach. He is the father and ex-coach of former professional tennis player [[Jelena Dokic]].<ref name="GuardianPicture">{{cite news |url=http://sport.guardian.co.uk/tennis/osm/story/0,,928762,00.html |title=Dad? He's out of the picture |work=[[The Guardian]] |date=April 6, 2003}}</ref> He gained notoriety for being involved in various violent incidents in which he was verbally and physically abusive.

Dokić is a self-proclaimed veteran of the [[Croatian War of Independence]], in which he fought on the side of the [[Serbs]].<ref name="jokeThreats">{{cite news|url=http://www.theage.com.au/world/threats-a-joke-dokic-tells-court-20090509-aybs.html?page=-1|title=Threats a joke, Dokic tells court|last=Milovanovic|first=Selma|date=2009-05-09|work=The Age|publisher=Fairfax|access-date=2009-05-22}}</ref> He also manufactures plum and pear "Eagle Brandy".<ref name="jokeThreats" />

At the [[2001 Australian Open]], after Jelena Dokic's first-round loss to [[Lindsay Davenport]], Dokić said that there were irregularities in the draw and that he was banned from the tournament due to abusive behavior. He later said "I think the draw is fixed just for her."<ref>{{cite web |url=http://sportsillustrated.cnn.com/tennis/2001/australian_open/news/2001/01/14/dokic_yugoslavia/ |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20010124100000/http://sportsillustrated.cnn.com/tennis/2001/australian_open/news/2001/01/14/dokic_yugoslavia/ |url-status=dead |archive-date=January 24, 2001 |title=Dokic to be recognized as Yugoslav at Open |website=[[Sports Illustrated]] |date=14 January 2001}}</ref> Prior to this, in 2000, he threw a piece of fish at a cafeteria worker at the US Open after complaining about paying $10 for a skimpy piece of fish. He was then banned from the tournament.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://nypost.com/2000/08/31/tennis-dad-ousted-after-noisy-racket/|title = Tennis Dad Ousted After Noisy Racket|date = 31 August 2000}}</ref>

During the [[2002 Australian Open]], he was featured in a series of advertisements for [[Kia Motors]], the title sponsor of the event, poking fun at his past misconduct. Kia defended the choice, citing 98 percent recognition of him and saying that he would not be too expensive.<ref name="SI">{{cite web |url=http://sportsillustrated.cnn.com/inside_game/jon_wertheim/news/2002/01/15/wertheim_insider/ |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20020208024904/http://sportsillustrated.cnn.com/inside_game/jon_wertheim/news/2002/01/15/wertheim_insider/ |url-status=dead |archive-date=February 8, 2002 |title=Strange choices Down Under |website=Sports Illustrated |date=January 15, 2002}}</ref>

In June 2009, after he threatened the Australian ambassador to [[Serbia]], [[Clare Birgin]],<ref>{{cite news |title=Jelena Dokic's Father on Hunger Strike |url=http://www.tennisnow.com/News/Jelena-Dokic’s-Father-on-Hunger-Strike.aspx |access-date=17 August 2020 |publisher=Tennis Now}}</ref> with a [[hand grenade]], Dokić was sentenced to 15 months in prison for causing public danger and for the illegal possession of weapons. He appealed against the sentence but it was upheld in September 2009.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/stories/2009/09/25/2696088.htm?section=justin|title=Jail sentence upheld for Dokic's dad|date=2009-09-25|work=ABC News|access-date=2009-09-25}}</ref> Following a further appeal, the sentence was reduced to 12 months<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/stories/2010/02/24/2828423.htm |title=Damir Dokic has jail sentence cut |work=ABC News |date=24 Feb 2010}}</ref> and Dokić was released from jail in April 2010.<ref>{{ cite news |url=http://www.dailytelegraph.com.au/news/helena-dokics-dad-damir-released-from-prison/story-e6freuy9-1225854343340 |title=Jelena Dokic's dad Damir released from prison |work=Daily Telegraph |date=16 Apr 2010}}</ref>

Jelena Dokic has stated that her father had abused her verbally, emotionally, and physically on a regular basis throughout her childhood and during her career, detailing the allegations in her autobiography, ''Unbreakable''.<ref>{{cite web |last1=De Silva |first1=Chris |title=Jelena Dokic shares chilling images from aftermath of brutal abuse during her career |url=https://wwos.nine.com.au/tennis/news-2023-jelena-dokic-shares-frightening-photos-of-abuse-from-father-damir/a4b862ce-4217-4d88-9348-dd407520e7b9 |website=wwos.nine.com.au |date=7 April 2023}}</ref> In a December 2023 interview, she stated that she had not spoken to her father for over 10 years, as he has never apologized to her for his behavior nor attempted to make amends.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Jackson |first1=Kieran |title=Jelena Dokic: 'I haven't spoken to my abusive father in 10 years – I sleep well at night' |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/sport/tennis/jelena-dokic-interview-australian-open-b2470000.html |work=The Independent |date=28 December 2023}}</ref>

==
